Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Nicholas R. Magliocca of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County to conduct a research project, entitled "Simulating the causes and consequences of local land-use change globally," during the summer of 2012 at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, China. The host scientist is Dr. He-Qing Huang.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to use a modeling framework to make a virtual laboratory for exploring the causal roles of demographic, economic and environmental factors that cannot be manipulated in the real world. and thus to shape a wide range of land-use systems globally and advance land-use theory.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective of this project was to conduct informal landscape surveys and interviews of land-use systems in China to support the development of a simulation model. The model is designed to investigate the influence of large-scale factors, such as economic globalization, on local land-use decision-making, and analyze the economic and ecological consequences of those decisions. When completed, this model will be applied to many different locations around the world to describe global patterns of land-use decision-making, and enrich our understanding of how local land-use might change in response to changing global market, demographic, and environmental conditions.

This project provided valuable "ground-truthing" of the model's design and application to sites in China. Site visits offered the unique opportunity to compare model features and inputs, such as satellite imagery, agricultural statistics, and representations of households, to those present in reality, and explore ways to more realistically model the natural landscape and people's land-use and livelihood decisions. Specifically, interviews with farmers enabled the comparison of different motivations for and constraints on land-use choices engaged in very different livelihoods. In addition, the interviews revealed different attitudes towards agricultural-based livelihoods among generations, as the younger generations tended to favor non-farm work in nearby cities rather than engaging in intensive commercial agriculture. This is an emerging trend in fast-developing China, and these findings can be incorporated into the model to more realistically represent people's livelihood choices with increasing economic development.

These preliminary findings provide first-steps to designing, testing, and validating general simulation models of local land-use that can be applied to multiple locations across the globe. Such simulation models advance of our ability to model, understand, and manipulate land-use systems in ways that would be impossible in the field.  This modeling framework provides a virtual laboratory for exploring the causal roles of demographic, economic and environmental factors in shaping a wide range of land-use systems globally. Ultimately, such an approach enables a more integrated global picture of land change processes to emerge. From that general picture, a more nuanced understanding of the global context and specific forces shaping particular regions is possible, which can more effectively target development policies to support both economic and environmental sustainability.

Beyond these specific research outcomes, the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes Program provided first-hand research experience outside of the U.S.. As China continues its ascent in global importance, the international collaborations established through this project will be increasingly valuable conduits for future research. In addition, this project fostered a deeper understanding of the structure of scientific organizations, policy, and conduct within China, as well as an orientation to Chinese society, culture, and language - all of which will be crucial for conducting research with international partners in the future.
